NEW PLAN WILL BE
TRIED NEXT YEAR

by the faculty in trying out
the New Plan was shown
late last week when circular
letters were sent to every
sophomore and junior. in the
University, giving the opportunity to exceptional students of proceeding to the
bachelor's degree under a
new systeni.

the new plan will be assigned their work by the department in which they will '

arithmetical point system,

subject to the approval of
the Board of Collegiate

TIMES BACKS NEW PLAN
HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 5, 1926.

• HOORAY—FOR A CAMPAIGN
The NEWS-LETTER has not been among the foremost in
howling for campaigns or 'drives' among the students and
alumni of the university. Now, however, comes a campaign for
which we are willing to yell until our poor vocal cords crack.
We refer to the coming "Spring Season Ticket Campaign."
Now we do not want to perpetrate any "Hoorah for dear
old Siwash" stuff. But we do want to impress upon the stu- •
dents the necessity of working hard at the business of selling
tickets. Hopkins teams may not be the leading college teams
of the country, but we are willing to ask the man who says that
Hopkins lacrosse is poor to step outside. And it is for the
lacrosse season that the tickets are to be sold. If the season
is not'a financial as well as an athletic success, the caliber of
the game, as played at Hopkins, will be lowered. • For, gad as
it may seem, it does take money to run a good team.
Consequently, we call upon every undergraduate who has
the welfare of athletics at Hopkins at heart to get out and
sell, sell, sell season tickets, that the campaign, for which we
howl, may be a success.

•

BACK 'EM UP!
Tonight the swimming team will tackle Loyola College in
the Knights of Columbus pool. This is the third meet of their
schedule which consists of but four home meets.
In all fairness the NEWS-LETTER asks every student to turn
out tonight for the races and dance.
It was not so long ago when wails went around the campus
bemoaning the lack of a winter sport at Johns Hopkins. Now,
after much work upon the part of those most interested, we
have a capable swimming team, an excellent pool, and a fair
league schedule, considering the short space of time in which
it was compiled. The Athletic Association is backing the meets
which are always followed by enjoyable dances in order to
make the events more enticing. Yet with all this only a handful of spectators turned out at the first two meets with Rutgers
and Delaware, in both of which Hopkins showed up well.
The Athletic Association has stobd the loss of money in
spite of its failing finances, but this does not make the outlook
bright for succeeding teams in the future.
Baseball has gone and it looks as though a similar fate
will be tarked to the swimming team, unless it is supported
much more strongly at the remaining two meets.
The NEWS-LETTER urges every man to attend the meet tonight not because we think he will enjoy himself and want to
advertise the team, but because of interest in the future of
sports at Hopkins.
C. F. R.

"The prompt fame of Johns
Hopkins brought college graduates of first quality from various
parts of the country. Woodrow

were among its earliest students.
But other universities soon, under

them."
At this point the editorial takes
up a general sketch of the history
of the American university and
of Johns Hopkins in particular.
It tells how, under the pressure
of competition, inadequate funds,
and the like, Hopkins, along with
other universities, was forced to
adopt a more elementary course
of study. This was, as a natural
consequence, followed by a great
increase in the number of undergraduates and their continued
domination in university life. The
pure university type, technically
speaking, no longer existed.
"However, under the leadership
of President Goodnow, the University Trustees have decided to return to the original ideal to make
it the university toward which
President Gilman looked when he
gathered a little group of great
scholars in their respective fields,
Sylvester, Gildersleeve, Remsen,
Brooks, Rowland, Adams, to lead
and stimulate graduate students
in original work."

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 5, 1926.

• HOORAY—FOR A CAMPAIGN
The NEWS-LETTER has not been among the foremost in
howling for campaigns or 'drives' among the students and
alumni of the university. Now, however, comes a campaign for
which we are willing to yell until our poor vocal cords crack.
We refer to the coming "Spring Season Ticket Campaign."
Now we do not want to perpetrate any "Hoorah for dear
old Siwash" stuff. But we do want to impress upon the stu- •
dents the necessity of working hard at the business of selling
tickets. Hopkins teams may not be the leading college teams
of the country, but we are willing to ask the man who says that
Hopkins lacrosse is poor to step outside. And it is for the
lacrosse season that the tickets are to be sold. If the season
is not'a financial as well as an athletic success, the caliber of
the game, as played at Hopkins, will be lowered. • For, gad as
it may seem, it does take money to run a good team.
Consequently, we call upon every undergraduate who has
the welfare of athletics at Hopkins at heart to get out and
sell, sell, sell season tickets, that the campaign, for which we
howl, may be a success.

•

BACK 'EM UP!
Tonight the swimming team will tackle Loyola College in
the Knights of Columbus pool. This is the third meet of their
schedule which consists of but four home meets.
In all fairness the NEWS-LETTER asks every student to turn
out tonight for the races and dance.
It was not so long ago when wails went around the campus
bemoaning the lack of a winter sport at Johns Hopkins. Now,
after much work upon the part of those most interested, we
have a capable swimming team, an excellent pool, and a fair
league schedule, considering the short space of time in which
it was compiled. The Athletic Association is backing the meets
which are always followed by enjoyable dances in order to
make the events more enticing. Yet with all this only a handful of spectators turned out at the first two meets with Rutgers
and Delaware, in both of which Hopkins showed up well.
The Athletic Association has stobd the loss of money in
spite of its failing finances, but this does not make the outlook
bright for succeeding teams in the future.
Baseball has gone and it looks as though a similar fate
will be tarked to the swimming team, unless it is supported
much more strongly at the remaining two meets.
The NEWS-LETTER urges every man to attend the meet tonight not because we think he will enjoy himself and want to
advertise the team, but because of interest in the future of
sports at Hopkins.
C. F. R.
